title: Live flood warnings in Gloucestershire with UK snow risk amid 2024 cold snap forecast
text:
There are now two red alert
Flood Warnings in place in Gloucestershire today (Friday, December 29) as the aftermath of Storm Gerrit continues to be felt. The warnings, which mean flooding is expected act now, are in place on the River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh and at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury.
More heavy rain is also in the
weather forecast for the county over the weekend, although it won't be as bad as we saw during the height of the storm. A deep area of low pressure is due to move in from the west to affect western parts of the UK, the Met Office said.
The worst of
Storm Gerrit has passed, the Met Office added. But the last few days of 2023 forecast to be unsettled with strong winds, rain and even snow on higher ground.
We'll have the latest on the flooding and the weather in the blog below. Scroll down for the latest
Want our best stories with fewer ads and alerts when the biggest news stories drop? Download our app on
iPhone or Android and comment on this story.
Full list of Flood Warnings and Flood Alerts
- River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh
- River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
- River Wye in North Hereford
- River Wye in South Hereford
- River Avon in Worcestershire
- River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
- River Frome in Herefordshire
- River Leadon catchment
- River Severn in Gloucestershire
- River Severn in Worcestershire
- River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade
- River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
- River Wye in Gloucestershire
- River Wye in Herefordshire
Reports of crash in Ledbury
This from Inrix:
Reports of heavy traffic due to accident on A438 in both directions at A417.
Storm Gerrit UK round-up
How the storm impacted the UK
- Thousands of homes remain without power as the post-storm cleanup begins in the wake of Storm Gerrit. Around 1,500 homes in Scotland experienced their second night without power in Scotland while a lightning strike hit supplies in Wales on Thursday.
- Three men died after their 4×4 vehicle was submerged in the River Esk, near Glaisdale, on Thursday, North Yorkshire Police said.
- A supercell thunderstorm moved across the northwest of England on Thursday after a similar storm is thought to have resulted in a tornado that damaged homes in Greater Manchester on Wednesday.
- Around 100 properties were damaged by what police called a “localised tornado” in Stalybridge, Tameside and in the badly-hit village of Carrbrook.
- ScotRail said many lines have been reopened but urged passengers to check for the latest information before travelling, a message echoed by LNER, Avanti West Coast and London Northwestern Railway who suspensed or cancelled services due to damage or system faults.
- Friday will see significant disruption for travellers wishing to travel on the London Euston and Watford Junction lines with services expected to be up and running by the end of the day.
- In Wales, the aftermath of the recent severe weather will see rail services hampered until Monday.
- Ferry services also experienced cancellations and delays due to storm activity with operator DFDS confirming sailings between Dover and France were delayed due to strong winds in the English Channel.
- Air travel in and out of the UK saw cancellations but most services have returned to normal.
M4 traffic update
Barrier repairs continue on the M4 Prince of Wales Bridge after a seven-vehicle crash on Wednesday.
One lane closed due to emergency barrier repairs on M4 Prince of Wales Bridge in both directions between J22 M49 and J23 M48. Traffic is coping well.
Friday's top stories
The latest headlines
M5 junction 10 revamp and Arle Court park and ride funding boost as Gloucestershire residents face 5% tax hike Hundreds oppose weekend music festival amid fears of 'alcohol-fuelled noise and disorder' Post-Christmas crime spree sees presents stolen from church and cars Massive scorpion found in Cotswolds village Doctors say 'it's too late' in calls for deadly baby virus vaccine
West Country weather forecast
Latest from the Met Office for the South West
Today: Another day of blustery showers, heavy at times, with some sunny spells. Staying rather mild and remaining breezy, especially in any heavy downpours though less windy than recent days. Maximum temperature 11 °C.
Tonight: Any day time showers gradually easing through the evening allowing for clearer skies for a time and lighter winds. Turning cloudier by dawn with some patchy rain from the west. Minimum temperature 4 °C.
Saturday: Turning unsettled with cloud and outbreaks of rain pushing in from the west. Rain turning heavy at times, especially later over the hills with strong gusty winds and coastal gales. Maximum temperature 12 °C.
Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Often cloudy on Sunday with some blustery showers in the west. Largely fine on New Year's Day with a few showers. Cloudier on Tuesday with rain and stronger winds.
M48 Severn Crossing traffic update
This from Inrix:
M48 Westbound closed due to strong winds at J1 A403 (Aust). This is in preparation for the increased winds speeds and an expected closure to high sided vehicles.
Diversion - via the exit and entry slips.
What to expect at end of 2023 and start of 2024
During the early hours of Saturday a potentially deep area of low pressure will move in from the west to affect Ireland and western parts of the UK, the Met Office says.
As the system moves eastwards, the boundary between the area of low pressure and the relatively colder conditions further north and east will lead to a band of transient snow across some of the high ground of northern England and Scotland. It is possible this snow could fall to lower levels for a brief period of time across Scotland.
What this means for the end of the year:
Steven Ramsdale, a Met Office Chief Forecaster, said:
This system is likely to bring a range of weather including hill snow. Heavy rain will spread across all but the far north on Saturday affecting similar areas previously affected by Storm Gerrit. However, this rainfall will be a step down from that seen during Storm Gerrit.
Looking into 2024
Nick Silkstone, a Met Office Deputy Chief Forecaster, said:
Through to mid-January, there is a signal for a shift in the pattern compared to the winter so far, with more settled and colder-than-average conditions becoming increasingly likely
Flood Warning for Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
This from the Environment Agency
River levels are rising at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.
We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury.
Predicted Peaks at Mythe 3.8m to 4m Friday overnight, Upper Pound 3.8m to 4m Friday overnight.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
Flood Warning for Apperley and The Leigh
This from the
Environment Agency
River levels have risen at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible [Thursday[ evening.
We expect flooding to affect Gabb Lane at Apperley and local caravan parks.
Predicted Peak at Haw Bridge 4.7m to 4.9m Saturday morning, 30/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Solve for h in the equation:-9h = 10 – 4h
l Step 1: Combine Like TermsTo solve the equation, start by moving all terms with h to one side. Add 4h to both sides to eliminate the -4h on the right:-9h + 4h = 10 – 4h + 4h
l Step 2: Simplify the EquationCombine the h terms on the left:-5h = 10

title: Hydrogen Fuel: Italian steel plant launches trial to use hydrogen to cut emissions, ET Manufacturing
text: Earlier in May, Italy, Germany and Austria signed a cooperation deal to develop a hydrogen transportation network from the southern Mediterranean to northern Europe.Italian gas grid operator Snam , steel pipe maker Tenaris and green technology firm Tenova are trialling the use of hydrogen fuel at a Tenaris steel plant in northern Italy in a bid to cut emissions, they said on Wednesday. According to a joint statement from the groups, the trial to use hydrogen fuel in a reheating furnace at the plant in Dalmine, near Bergamo, will last six months. It will track the performance and reliability of using hydrogen in the steel industry, the statement said, and is part of Snam's broader move to help industrial companies decarbonise. Hydrogen's main by-product as a fuel is water vapour, along with small amounts of nitrogen oxides, making it far less polluting than fossil fuels - assuming it does not cause further pollution via leaks. Earlier in May, Italy, Germany and Austria signed a cooperation deal to develop a hydrogen transportation network from the southern Mediterranean to northern Europe.

author: Israel Ojoko
title: Reviving the Sahara: Ancient Rainwater Harvesting Methods and Sustainable Land Management
text:
Imagine unearthing a time when the vast Sahara was a vibrant tapestry of grasslands, a stark contrast to the expansive desert we know today. This transformation, rooted in a mega drought that occurred around 4,000 years ago, serves as a poignant reminder of the Earth's vulnerability to drastic climate shifts. In recent times, the spotlight turns towards the Sahel countries, lying on the cusp of the Sahara, grappling with the specter of desertification. As the world convenes to address climate change, the wisdom of ancient rainwater harvesting methods emerges as a beacon of hope, aimed at revitalizing the Sahara and safeguarding its future.
The Sands of Time: Understanding the Sahara's Past
The story of the Sahara is not just one of loss but also of adaptation and resilience. Once a flourishing grassland home to diverse ecosystems, the desert's transformation was a consequence of natural climate variability. This historical perspective is crucial, as it underscores the dynamic nature of our planet's climate system and the human capacity to adapt to changing environments. The vulnerability of the Sahel countries to desertification is not just a testament to the changing climate but also a call to action for innovative solutions to combat these changes.
Reviving Ancient Wisdom in Modern Times
At the heart of the fight against desertification is the quest to harness ancient knowledge for contemporary challenges. El Habib Ben Amara, an architect, urban designer, and fervent activist against desertification, is at the forefront of this battle. Growing up in a ksar, a fortified village in Algeria, Ben Amara was imbued with the teachings of resilience and sustainability passed down through generations. These ksour, surrounded by oases, were bastions of agroforestry, creating a symbiosis between nature and human ingenuity. However, the encroaching forces of urbanization and socio-economic mismanagement have threatened these ancient systems, turning once-abundant resources into scarcities.
In response, there's a burgeoning movement to reintegrate oasis agricultural techniques and salvage the precious knowledge contained within the palm groves and the ruins of ksour settlements. This initiative is not merely about agricultural productivity but a holistic approach to restoring ecological balance and fostering sustainable communities. By addressing water scarcity through ancient rainwater harvesting methods, there's a pathway to not only reviving the Sahara but also mitigating global challenges such as food security and poverty.
Combating Desertification: A Global Imperative
The recent event hosted by the United Nations University, featuring Ibrahim Thiaw, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification, underscored the importance of addressing desertification as a global security issue. Thiaw highlighted the interconnections between desertification, land degradation, drought, and water scarcity with global security, food security, poverty eradication, and sustainable development. Sustainable land management practices stand as a cornerstone for combating these intertwined challenges, offering a blueprint for resilience and sustainability.
The narrative of desertification is not one of inevitable decline but of potential rebirth. It's a narrative that calls for a rekindling of ancient wisdom, tailored to meet the exigencies of the present and future. By embracing sustainable land management and ancient rainwater harvesting methods, there's hope for regions like the Sahara to not only survive but thrive amid the challenges of climate change. This journey towards sustainability is not just about combating desertification but about reimagining our relationship with the land, fostering a harmonious coexistence between humanity and nature.
In essence, the Sahara's transformation from grassland to desert and the ongoing efforts to combat desertification encapsulate a broader story of human resilience and adaptability. It's a story that transcends borders, reminding us of our collective responsibility to steward the Earth's resources wisely. As we look to the ancient wisdom of rainwater harvesting and sustainable land management, let us also envision a future where the Sahara and similar regions flourish once again, serving as testaments to what can be achieved when humanity harmonizes with nature.
